questions.text: A male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. He gives a history of consuming raw refrigerated vegetables 24 hours back. What is the type of motility shown by the most likely etiologic organism when it is cultured at 25°C?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of food poisoning caused by Listeria monocytogenes. Listeria monocytogenes shows slow tumbling motility when grown at 25°C. 

L. monocytogenes is a short, Gram-positive, non-spore-forming rod. It is catalase positive and has tumbling end-over-end motility at 22–28°C but is non-motile at 37°C. This is because the peritrichous flagella are produced by the bacillus optimally between 20°C and 30°C.

It enters the body through the gastrointestinal tract after ingestion of contaminated foods such as cheese, fruit, or vegetables especially refrigerated items (the bacteria survives well at 4°C in the refrigerator). It causes a mild, self-limiting febrile gastroenteritis which lasts for 1–3 days. The incubation period is 6–48 hours. Symptoms include fever, chills, headache, myalgias, abdominal pain, and diarrhea.

The drug of choice is ampicillin with gentamicin.

The image below shows the tumbling motility of L. monocytogenes.

Other options:

Swarming motility is seen with Bacillus cereus. It has two distinct forms: the emetic type, which is associated with fried rice, milk, and pasta, and the diarrheal type, which is associated with meat dishes and sauces. The incubation period for the emetic group is 30 minutes to 6 hours and they present with nausea and vomiting. The incubation period for the diarrheal group is 6 - 15 hours and they present with watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps.

Darting motility is seen with Vibrio cholerae. It is actively motile with a polar flagellum. It results in watery diarrhea with characteristic rice watery stools. Shellfish (oysters), especially raw and undercooked food, are the common source for Vibrio species, especially V. parahaemolyticus. 

Falling motility is seen with Giardia lamblia. It is the common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum of humans. Infection is acquired by the consumption of water or food contaminated with cysts and may also be transmitted by the feco-oral route. The symptoms include acute or chronic diarrhoea, weight loss, malaise, abdominal cramps, distension, and weakness.

questions.text: A microbiology resident has been posted in the virology laboratory to study the structure and shape and symmetry of viruses. Using an electron microscope he would be able to resolve points that are _____ apart.
questions.solution:
Using an electron microscope the resident would be able to resolve points that are 0.1 nm apart, which is the resolving power of an electron microscope.

Ernst Ruska designed the first electron microscope, enabling us to view viruses.

In an electron microscope, a beam of electrons is used instead of a beam of light used in the optical microscope. The electron beam is focused by circular electromagnets (analogous to the lenses in the light microscope). The object which is present in the path of the beam scatters the electrons and produces an image that is focused on a fluorescent viewing screen.

The wavelength of electrons used is approximately 0.005 nm and in practice, the resolving power of the electron microscope is about 0.1 nm.

Techniques used with an electron microscope:

  • Shadow-casting with vaporised heavy metals: This makes pictures with good contrast and three-dimensional effect possible.
  • Negative staining with phosphotungstic acid: This allows for studying of fine structures.
  • Freeze-etching by deep-freezing specimens in a liquid gas and subsequently forming carbon-platinum replicas of the material. This enables the study of the cellular ultrastructure as it appears in the living state.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy returned from a birthday party and began vomiting 4-5 hours later, followed by a few episodes of loose stools, but had no fever. Other children who had attended the party reported a similar illness. Food samples were collected and sent for toxin detection by a test based on the following principle. This test is known as:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Sandwich ELISA. The above clinical scenario is suggestive of food poisoning caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

The symptoms of food poisoning caused by S aureus appear within 1-8 hours. Multiple people are exposed to the pathogen from a common source and present with vomiting, loose stools but no fever. Foods from outbreaks of food poisoning is examined for the presence of staphylococcal enterotoxin A (SEA) by a sandwich ELISA.

ELISA (Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) involves the use of an immunosorbent, which is an absorbing material that is specific for one of the components of the reaction, either the antigen or antibody. This may be a particulate phase (cellulose or agarose), or a solid phase (polystyrene, polyvinyl, or polycarbonate tubes or microwells). ELISA is done using 96-well microtitre plates suitable for automation.

Sandwich ELISA is used for antigen detection in the patient samples. The antigen is sandwiched between two layers of antibodies - capture and detection antibodies.

The following steps are followed in Sandwich ELISA:

  1. The capture antibody is immobilized on a microtiter well.
  2. A sample containing antigen is added and allowed to react with the immobilized antibody.
  3. After the well is washed, a second enzyme-linked antibody (Detecting antibody) specific to the antigen is added and allowed to react with the bound antigen.
  4. After any free second antibody is removed by washing, the substrate is added. This substrate is converted by the enzyme to detectable colored form and the colored reaction product is measured.

Other options:

Option A: Cassette ELISA: Here, each specimen is tested in a separate disposable cassette and gives rapid results (10-15 minutes). There is no need for microplate washers or readers and the result can be read visually. Example: Dot Blot Assay used for the detection of HIV type 1 and 2 antibodies.

Option C: Competitive ELISA: Both the unknown antigen (sample) and the known antigen (standard) compete with each other for a fixed amount of antibody.

Option D: Indirect ELISA: Antibody in the sample can be detected or quantitatively measured using this method. Serum or some other sample containing primary antibody (Ab1) is added to an antigen-coated microtiter well and allowed to react. Enzyme-conjugated secondary anti-isotype antibody (Ab2) is added which binds to the primary antibody.

The given image shows steps followed in different types of ELISA.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct with respect to decreasing order of oxygen required for growth?
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the organisms in descending order of oxygen requirement for growth is Mycobacterium TB > Mycobacterium bovis > Clostridium, which are obligatory aerobes, microaerophilic, and anaerobes, respectively.

Depending on the influence of oxygen on growth and viability, bacteria are divided into aerobes and anaerobes. They are further divided as;

  • Obligate aerobes will grow only in the presence of oxygen. They obtain their energy and intermediates only through oxidation, using oxygen as the ultimate hydrogen acceptor. This process of conversion of ADP to ATP using oxygen is called oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Facultative anaerobes are ordinarily aerobic but can also grow in the absence of oxygen, though less abundantly. Most bacteria of medical importance are facultative anaerobes.
  • Anaerobes can grow even in the absence of oxygen. They obtain energy by the process of fermentation and substrate-level phosphorylation.
  • Obligate anaerobes may even die on exposure to oxygen. This is because of the absence of the enzyme catalase, which acts on the toxic metabolite hydrogen peroxide formed in the presence of oxygen. Another reason is that they possess essential enzymes that are active only in the reduced state.
  • Microaerophilic bacteria grow best in the presence of low oxygen tension.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes with multiple circular, dry, scaly, itchy lesions on the scalp.  On further examination, it is seen that hair is involved but nails are spared. Scrapings from the lesion are inoculated and examined microscopically. Identify the dermatophyte based on the macroconidia seen in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of tinea capitis and the image showing large spindle-shaped macroconidia is a feature of Microsporum.

Dermatophytosis (commonly called tinea or ringworm) refers to infection of keratinized structures (the skin, hair, and nails) caused by a group of keratinophilic fungi, called the dermatophytes.

Dermatophytes are classified into 3 types:

  • Trichophyton infects skin, hair, and nails. The species include T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc. Microconidia > Macroconidia
  • Microsporum infects only hair and skin but, not the nails. The species include M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. Macroconidia> Microconidia.
  • Epidermophyton infects only skin and nails, not hair. Floccosum is the only species in this genus. Only Macroconidia.

Clinical features of infection by Microsporum include:

  • Skin lesions in the skin tend to be circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy.
  • Hair lesions include kerion, scarring, and alopecia.

Diagnosis is established by clinical features, the use of Wood's lamp, and laboratory investigations such as microscopic examination and culture characteristics.

Microscopic examination of material teased out from the fungal colony (culture mount) or material taken on cellotape (cellotape mount) is observed for identification of the species. It is observed for the presence and type of hyphae and conidia. Conidia (asexual spores) are of two types: small unicellular microconidia and larger septate macroconidia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with a productive cough, low-grade fever with an evening rise in temperature over the last 3 months, and blood-tinged sputum over the last four days. An early morning sputum sample was taken for culture and inoculated into two bottles of the following medium. Identify the culture medium shown below:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is that of tuberculosis and the culture medium shown in the image is the Lowenstein-Jenson medium.

It is a selective medium used for the culture of Mycobacterium tuberculosis which causes tuberculosis. The presence of malachite green imparts a green color and makes Lowenstein Jenson medium a selective media by inhibiting other bacteria. 

Components of LJ medium:

  • Egg: Provide fatty acids and protein required for the metabolism.
  • Malachite green: Prevents growth of contaminants.
  • Mineral salt solution: Buffer.
  • Glycerol: Source of carbon, Favours growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. Bovis.
  • L-asparagine: Source of Nitrogen. 

Colony characteristics on LJ Medium:

Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are rough, raised, irregular colonies that are creamy white, and buff-colored. (rough, tough, buff). They do not emulsify in a saline solution.

Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

  • Solid culture media: Lowenstein–Jensen (A commonly used, egg-based, selective media).
  • Liquid culture media: Dubos' media, Middle Brook’s media. Virulent strains tend to form long serpentine cords in liquid media, while avirulent strains grow in a more dispersed manner.
  • Automated Culture Media: 
    • BACTEC 460: Uses radioisotopes
    • BacT/ALERT: A colorimetric method
    • BACTEC MGIT: A fluorometric detection method. 

Other options:

Option A: BacT Alert culture medium uses a colorimetric method for indication of mycobacterial growth, by detecting the CO2 produced during growth. An image of BacT/ALERT blood culture tubes is given below. 

Option B: Loeffler's serum slope is a medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheria. Rapid growth occurs within 6-8 hours. Colonies appear at first as small, opaque discs. They increase in size on continued incubation and may acquire a yellow tint.

It is shown in the image below.

Option D: Middlebrook’s media is a liquid culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with fever, hypotension, and skin rash. She had a tampon in situ for 24 hours. Which of the following toxin is not involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
A patient with fever, hypotension, and skin rash after retaining a tampon for 24 hours likely has toxic shock syndrome. The exfoliative toxin is not involved in this condition.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a multisystem toxin-mediated disease caused by Staphylococcus aureus. Toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1) produced by S. aureus is most commonly implicated in TSS. TSST-1 is a superantigen. It binds to MHC class II molecules and causes T-cell stimulation by bypassing the normal activation pathway. This leads to the overactivation of cytokines and inflammatory cells leading to toxic shock syndrome. Staphyloccoccal enterotoxin B is the second most common cause of TSS and recently, streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin has also been implicated.  

Toxic shock syndrome generally occurs in menstruating women who use superabsorbent tampons and do not change them often. However, it can also occur in post-surgical infections, burns, soft tissue infections, and retained foreign bodies like nasal packing, and catheters. Patients present with fever, desquamative skin rash, hypotension, and multisystem organ involvement. Treatment involves prompt removal of the source of infection such as tampons, nasal packing or debridement. Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be administered after culture samples have been taken. The patient should also receive aggressive hydration with crystalloids. 

Exfoliative toxin causes staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome. Neonates are generally affected and present with fever, lethargy, poor feeding followed by rash and formation of large fluid-filled blisters. These blisters often burst which leads to exposed mucosa.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was brought with forgetfulness, behavioral changes, and visual hallucinations for the past 4 months. He is not able to button his shirt and tie his shoelaces for the last 1 month. Diagnosis of a subacute spongiform encephalopathy is made. This is caused by:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of memory loss with incoordination is suggestive of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a type of subacute spongiform encephalopathy, which is caused by prions.

Prions are proteinaceous infective particles that are transmissible. They are virus-like agents devoid of nucleic acid. They are small particles, resistant to heat, UV rays, and nucleases, and sensitive to proteases.

The pathogenic mechanism is the proliferation of an abnormal prion protein (PrPsc) which is derived from the normal cellular prion protein (PrPc). The accumulation of PrPsc in the CNS as diffuse deposits and in the form of plaques disrupts the architecture and function of the brain.

They are slow viral diseases that produce chronic progressive degenerative diseases of the CNS. They are collectively called subacute spongiform encephalopathies and includes Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, kuru and Gerstmann-Sträussler syndrome. Most of these diseases are rapidly progressive and even fatal.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a human prion disease. It is subacute, presenile encephalopathy, with progressive incoordination and dementia, ending fatally in about a year. Both sporadic and inherited forms of the disease have been seen. Iatrogenic CJD has occurred after corneal transplantation and injection of the pituitary growth hormone, presumably from donors who had the infection.

Other options:

Option A: Lentivirus belongs to a group A slow viruses. It causes a slowly progressive infection in sheep. 

Option B: Cryptosporidium parvum causes chronic profuse diarrhea in immunocompromised patients, which can lead to water and electrolyte depletion and weight loss.

Option D: Burkholderia cepacia usually causes fatal necrotizing pneumonia in cystic fibrosis patients.

questions.text: The 8-year-old child with delayed development was referred for evaluation of recurrent infections. History is notable for the presence of congenital heart defects. Further examination reveals the presence of a cleft palate and workup reveals the presence of hypocalcemia.  Which component of the immune system is likely to be affected in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with developmental delay, recurrent infections with a history of congenital heart disease and examination revealing cleft palate and hypocalcemia point towards the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome. Cell-mediated immunity is affected.

DiGeorge syndrome is a complex embryopathy with an autosomal dominant inheritance that is caused by microdeletions in the long arm of chromosome 22, leading to multiple developmental defects.

Children with DiGeorge syndrome have thymic hypoplasia resulting in T-cell immunodeficiency. The disease may range from mildly increased susceptibility to infections to a severe disease requiring a thymic or hematopoietic stem cell transplant. Patients are generally able to cope with extracellular bacterial infections because their innate and T cell-independent antibody responses are intact, but they cannot effectively eliminate intracellular pathogens such as viruses, intracellular bacteria, and fungi.

The clinical features of this syndrome include:

  • Congenital heart disease- aortic arch anomalies
  • Abnormalities of the palate like cleft palate.
  • Facial dysmorphisms such as hypertelorism, antimongoloid slant, low set ears, micrognathia, short philtrum, and bifid uvula.
  • Thymic hypoplasia with impaired T cell immunity. 
  • Parathyroid hypoplasia resulting in hypocalcemia (tetany).

Interestingly individuals with DiGeorge syndrome are at high risk for psychotic illnesses such as schizophrenia and bipolar disorders.

Diagnosis is established only by the detection of deletion in long-arm chromosome 22 by fluorescent in-situ hybridisation(FISH).

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with lepromatous leprosy was administered a 'transfer factor' containing competent lymphocytes to improve his immunity. Which of the following types of immunity is offered by this treatment?
questions.solution:
The administration of the transfer factor provides adoptive immunity, which is a special type of immunity.

Adoptive immunity is immunity in which immunologically competent lymphocytes are injected. The transfer factor is composed of these immunologically competent lymphocytes. It can passively transfer cell-mediated immunity against those antigens to which the donor is sensitive.

Adoptive immunity is different from adaptive immunity. 

Adaptive immunity/ active immunity is the resistance developed by an individual as a result of an antigenic stimulus. It is known as adaptive immunity as it represents the adaptive response of the host to a specific pathogen or another antigen.

Types of immunity: 

  • Natural active immunity: It results from either a clinical or an inapparent infection by a microbe. For e.g, A person who has recovered from an attack of measles develops natural active immunity against measles.
  • Artificial active immunity: It is the resistance induced by vaccines which are preparations of killed or attenuated microorganisms or their products. For e.g, the BCG vaccine induces immunity against TB
  • Natural passive immunity: It is the immunity passively transferred from mother to baby. In human infants, maternal antibodies are transmitted predominantly through the placenta, while in animals such as pigs, the transfer of antibodies occurs mainly through the colostrum. The human colostrum is also rich in lgA antibodies and gives protection to the neonate
  • Artificial passive immunity: It is the resistance passively transferred to a recipient by the administration of antibodies. Hyperimmune sera of animal or human origin, convalescent sera, pooled human immunoglobulin are used for this purpose. For e.g, anti-tetanus serum, anti-diphtherial serum.
  • Combined immunization: Sometimes a combination of the active and passive methods of immunization is used; Antisera and vaccine are given at the same time. For e.g, in the protection of a non-immune individual with a tetanus-prone wound, tetanus immunoglogulin (TIG) is injected in one arm, with a full course of tetanus toxoid in the other. This is followed by full course of tetanus toxoid vaccine. TIG provides the protection necessary till active immunity is able to take effect.

questions.text:
Which of the following test(s) is/are used for determining the efficiency of a disinfectant ?
  1. Rideal-Walker test
  2. Chick Martin test
  3. Kelsey-Sykes test
  4. In-use test
questions.solution:
All of the above tests are used for determining the efficiency of a disinfectant.

The Rideal-Walker test helps in determining the phenol co-efficient (PC) which indicates the power of a disinfectant. A PC value of more than 1 indicates that it is more effective than phenol. The higher the number, the greater its effectiveness in comparison to phenol and vice versa. It is only of historical value. St. aureus and Salmonella enteric subtype typhi were the organisms that were traditionally used for this test.

Chick Martin test: This is a modification of Rideal-Walker test in which the disinfectants acts in the presence of organic matter like feces or yeast to simulate natural conditions.

Kelsey-Sykes test (capacity test): It tests the capacity of a disinfectant to retain its activity when used repeatedly. This is used now.

In-use test: It determines whether the chosen disinfectant is effective in actual hospital use. This is used now.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man had  presented to the clinic with a history of chronic cough. His chest X-ray showed a mass in the left lung with hilar lymphadenopathy. Biopsy of the mass was done and findings are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the presence of tiny yeast forms within macrophages are suggestive of Histoplasmosis which is also called Darling's disease. Other names of this condition include Cave's disease and Ohio disease.

The causative agent is a dimorphic fungus called Histoplasma capsulatum. Transmission occurs via inhalation of conidia. After inhalation, the conidia develop into yeast cells and are engulfed by alveolar macrophages. Within macrophages, the yeasts may disseminate to reticuloendothelial tissues, such as the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and lymph nodes.

Biopsy reveals tiny (2-4 microns) oval-shaped yeast cells inside macrophages.

On culture and microscopy, tuberculate macroconidia and hyaline septate mold with microconidia are seen. Diagnosis is mainly by urinary or blood antigens. 

It is treated using azole antifungals.

questions.text: A 40-year-old HIV patient who presented with dry, non-productive cough and dyspnea is diagnosed to have Pneumocystis jirovecii infection. Which of the following statements is false about this organism?

choices.text: Cyst wall stains black with methenamine silver stain
It grows readily on Sabouraud agar
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is used for prophylaxis in HIV patients

questions.solution:
Among the following statements, the false statement is that "Pneumocystis jirovecii grows readily on Sabouraud agar".

P. jirovecii is an extracellular pathogen that primarily resides in the lung's surfactant layer, impairing oxygen exchange and leading to symptoms like cyanosis. Diagnosis involves examining specimens from bronchoalveolar lavage, lung biopsies, or induced sputum for trophozoites and cysts using specialized stains and fluorescent microscopy. Culture methods are ineffective for diagnosis, and serological tests mainly determine infection prevalence rather than aiding clinical diagnosis. Detection of a specific surface glycoprotein in serum is indicative of acute infection.

P. jirovecii has three morphological forms:

  • Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped
  • Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase
  • Cyst - thick-walled, spherical in shape. It contains intracystic bodies

Trophozoites can be demonstrated by Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains. The cyst wall stains black with methenamine silver stain.

P. jirovecii causes pneumonia primarily in immunocompromised patients. It is commonly found in animals like rats and mice without causing disease unless the host's immune system is weakened. In humans, it historically affected malnourished infants and those undergoing immunosuppressive therapies, becoming a major cause of mortality in AIDS patients before effective preventive treatments. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMZ) and pentamidine isothionate are the drugs of choice for the treatment of acute cases. TMP-SMZ is also used for prophylaxis in HIV patients.

questions.text:
A mother brings her 9-month-old baby to the immunization clinic. The baby is scheduled to receive the booster dose of his Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV 13). Which of the following statements are true about the vaccine in question?
  1. Includes the capsular polysaccharide of 13 serotypes of S. pneumoniae 
  2. Revaccination is not recommended after an anaphylactic reaction to the 1st dose
  3. The vaccine should be stored at <2 °C and kept frozen
  4. HIV-positive children benefit from a booster dose
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 4 are true.

Pneumococcal vaccines include:

  • Pneumococcal conjugate vaccines (PCV): 10-valent (PCV10) and 13-valent (PCV13)
  • Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV): 23-valent polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23)

The Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) 13: It includes purified capsular polysaccharides of 13 serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae conjugated to a nontoxic variant of diphtheria toxin. Both PCV10 and PCV13 are preservative-free and their recommended storage temperature is 2-8°C. The vaccine must not be frozen.

WHO recommends 3 primary doses or 2 primary doses plus one booster of the PCV vaccine. In India, 2 primary doses at 6 and 14 weeks and 1 booster is given at 9-12 months.

Mild reactions like erythema and tenderness may occur, but systemic reactions are not known to occur. Revaccination is not recommended for those who had an anaphylactic reaction to the initial dose.

Regardless of the presence of underlying medical conditions (e.g., children with HIV infection, sickle cell disease, or who are otherwise immunocompromised), PCV should be given according to the national schedule. PCV is safe and well-tolerated among HIV-infected children. Children with HIV infection require a booster dose to sustain protection.

When primary immunization is initiated with one of these vaccines, it is recommended that the remaining doses are administered with the same product. WHO recommends the inclusion of PCVs in childhood immunization programs worldwide. 

Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine - PPSV23: It contains polysaccharide antigen from 23 types of pneumococcal bacteria and is available for adults and children over 2 years of age. Children under 2 years of age and immunocompromised individuals do not respond well to the vaccine. It is recommended for selected groups such as:

  • Post splenectomy
  • Sickle-cell disease
  • Chronic diseases of heart, lung, liver, or kidney
  • Generalized malignancies
  • Organ transplants

questions.text: A child presented with diarrhea, cough, and wheezing for the past 6 months. He is underweight and stunted for his age. Blood tests showed mild eosinophilia. The appearance of eggs in the stool specimen is shown below. The likely cause is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing an oval egg with rhabditiform larvae indicate infection by Strongyloides stercoralis.

The worm is ovoviviparous. The eggs contain fully formed larvae that hatch out immediately.

 Characteristics of the egg of Strongyloides stercoralis:

  • Thin-walled
  • Transparent
  • Ovoid in shape
  • Contain the rhabditiform (first stage) larva.

It is unique among human nematodes as it has a parasitic cycle and a free-living soil cycle, during which it persists for a long duration in the soil. The image given below shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.

The infective form of Strongyloides is the filariform larva. When a person walks barefoot on soil containing the infective filariform larvae, they penetrate the skin and enter the circulation. Then, they migrate to the small intestine.

Here, the larvae molt twice and become adult female worms. The eggs laid by the female in the intestinal mucosa hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

This autoinfection is not seen in Ancylostoma or Necator life cycle.

Strongyloidiasis (infection caused by S. stercoralis) is generally benign and asymptomatic. The clinical disease may have cutaneous (dermatitis at the site of penetration, perianal pruritis, urticaria), pulmonary (bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, asthma) and intestinal manifestations (mucus diarrhea, dysentery).

The rhabditiform larva (not the egg) in feces can be seen under a microscope, and eosinophilia in the blood is diagnostic of the disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented with bilateral lower limb non-pitting edema and milky white urine. On examination, a hydrocele was also seen. A night sample of blood is taken and is sent for thick and thin stained smears. The following image seen on the blood smear shows which organism?
questions.solution:
The image shows Wuchereria bancrofti. The clinical picture is suggestive of elephantiasis. The image demonstrates sheathed microfilaria with nuclei-free tail tip.

The disease can present as classical filariasis or occult filariasis. Clinical features include:

Classical filariasis- Fever, lymphangitis, hydrocele, elephantiasis(non-pitting brawny edema), milky white urine(chylous), etc.

Occult filariasis- Massive eosinophilia, hepatosplenomegaly, dyspnea, arthritis, glomerulonephritis, etc. 

Diagnosis is confirmed by the demonstration of microfilaria in blood, chylous urine, exudate of lymph varix, and hydrocele fluid.  The filarial species is nocturnally periodic,  hence it is preferable to collect night blood samples between 10 pm and 4 am. Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice.

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient presents with fever and cough, with a history of a visit to China and the consumption of pickled crayfish. He now complains of rusty sputum and cough which is suggestive of Paragonimus westermani infection. What is the infective form of this fluke?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of Paragonimus westermani (oriental lung fluke) infection. Metacercariae encysted in crab or crayfish is the infective form.

Paragonimus westermani is a trematode. The transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The parasite is endemic to Japan, Korea, Taiwan, China, and Southeast Asia. Endemic foci of P. westermani are present in Manipur.

Definitive host: Man, and many other crab-eating mammals and domestic animals

First intermediate host: Freshwater snail

Second intermediate host: Freshwater crab or crayfish.

The adult worms live in the respiratory tract of the definitive host in cystic spaces surrounded by a fibrous capsule formed by the host tissues. Unembryonated eggs escape into the bronchi and are coughed up and voided in sputum or swallowed and passed in feces. 

Clinical features include cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. There is viscous sputum speckled with golden-brown eggs. Demonstration of the eggs in sputum or feces provides definitive evidence.

Praziquantel (25 mg/ kg TDS for 1-2 days) is the drug of choice.

questions.text: A patient with a recent history of having consumed pork presented to the hospital with severe headache, vomiting, episodes of convulsions, and dies. The brain autopsy shows numerous small cysts containing scolices in a milky fluid. Which of the following is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and the autopsy findings of multiloculated cystic lesions are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by T. solium (Cysticercosis cellulosae).

Neurocysticercosis is the most common CNS parasitic infection. 

The pork tapeworm T. solium can cause two distinct forms of infection in humans: (1) adult tapeworms in the intestine or (2) larval forms (cysticerci) in the tissues (called cysticercosis). By ingesting undercooked pork containing cysticerci, humans acquire infections that lead to intestinal tapeworms. Infections that cause human cysticercosis follow the ingestion of T. solium eggs.

In cysticercosis, the clinical manifestations are variable. Cysticerci can be found anywhere in the body, most commonly detected in the brain, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), skeletal muscle, subcutaneous tissue, or eye. Neurologic manifestations (neurocysticercosis) are the most common. The clinical features of neurocysticercosis include

  • Features of increased intracranial tension like headache, nausea, ataxia, confusion, papilloedema, and altered mental status
  • Epilepsy
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Psychiatric disturbances
  • Meningoencephalitis
  • Transient paresis
  • Behavioral disorders
  • Aphasia
  • Visual disturbances.

Definitive diagnosis of cysticercosis is by biopsy of the lesion and its microscopic examination to show the invaginated scolex with suckers and hooks. Neuroimaging criteria include detection of dead calcified cysts by CT scan of brain. The cysticercal lesions appear as a small ring like hypodensities with a bright central spot. Clinical criteria includes detection of specific anticysticercal antibodies or cysticercal antigens by well- standardized immunodiagnostic tests. 

NOTE:

About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis.

questions.text: A brain autopsy findings of an HIV-positive woman with dementia is given below. Her medical records show that she had progressive weakness on the right side of the body. Which of the following is the most likely opportunistic co-infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with brain autopsy findings showing ballooned oligodendrocytes with nuclear inclusion bodies suggests progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). It is caused by the JC virus.

PML is a fatal subacute progressive demyelinating disease. It is caused by the neurotrophic JC virus which belongs to the family polyomavirus. The virus preferentially infects oligodendrocytes, demyelination throughout the brain is its principal pathologic effect, but spares the spinal cord and optic nerves.

It is an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised individuals and patients receiving monoclonal antibodies (for multiple sclerosis) and biological agents.

Patients present with insidious onset and steady progression of focal symptoms that include visual deficits (typically homonymous hemianopia), mental impairment (dementia, confusion, personality change), hemiparesis, and ataxia.

Diagnosis is with the help of an MRI brain which shows single or multiple confluent demyelinating lesions in the periventricular white matter. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) of the CSF is highly specific for the detection of JC virus in patients with PML.

No effective therapy is available for PML, but a 5-HT2a receptor antagonist mirtazapine is found to have beneficial effects.

The image given below shows a brain biopsy of a PML patient showing ballooned oligodendrocytes (blue arrow) with SV40 positive nuclear inclusion bodies (red arrow) and, enlarged astrocytes (yellow arrow) indicative of JC virus infection.

Other options:

Option A: Coxsackievirus B2 causes aseptic meningitis. Patients present with fever, malaise, headache, nausea, and abdominal pain. It may progress to mild muscle weakness.

Option B: Toxoplasma gondii causes toxoplasmosis, especially in immunocompromised patients. It is usually associated with a history of consumption of undercooked meat. Patients present with fever, headache, and focal neurologic deficits. MRI shows ring-enhancing lesions in the brain.

Option C: Herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV 2) can cause neurological disease (meningitis or encephalitis) presenting with fever, focal neurological deficit, and seizures. It shows focal lesions (in the temporal region) on MRI. It is diagnosed by PCR testing of HSV DNA in the CSF sample.

questions.text: During antibody screening for Hepatitis B infection, the following class of antibodies against HbcAg was detected in high titres in a patient. What is the most probable Hepatitis B infection status of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pentameric immunoglobulin, hence it is an IgM antibody. High titers of IgM antibodies signify a recent infection.

IgM antibody acts against the core antigen (IgM anti-Hbc) of Hepatitis B virus (HBV) and is predominant in acute infections. Later, it is replaced by IgG antibodies (IgG anti-Hbc).

Specific diagnosis of hepatitis B rests on the serological demonstration of the viral markers:

  • HBsAg is the first marker seen in the blood following infection and can be detected prior to the clinical manifestation and elevation of transaminases. Typically, they disappear within about two months of the start of clinical disease, but may sometimes persist for six months. Anti-HBs antibodies appear when the antigens are no longer detectable and they remain for very long periods. Anti-HBs are the protective antibody.
  • HBcAg cannot be demonstrated in circulation since it lies enclosed within the HBsAg coat, but its antibody, anti-HBc is the earliest marker seen in blood a week or two after the appearance of HBsAg. It remains for a lifetime and thus indicates a prior infection.
  • HBeAg appears in blood along with HBsAg or following its appearance. Circulating HBeAg is an indicator of active intrahepatic viral replication, and the presence of DNA polymerase, HBV DNA, and virions, reflect high infectivity.

Other options:

Option B: Remote HBV infection is characterized by the presence of IgG anti-Hbc antibodies.

Option C: People vaccinated against Hep B will have antibodies only against surface antigen HbsAg, and not against the core antigen. 

Option D: Hepatitis B carriers have IgG and HBsAg seen.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought with bilateral cheek swelling,  pain, tenderness, and fever for the last two days. Which of the following is not a complication of this infection?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a parotid swelling with fever is suggestive of mumps infection. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is not a complication of this disease. SSPE is caused by a measles infection.

Mumps is an infection caused by the mumps virus, a paramyxovirus. It causes non-suppurative inflammation and growth of the parotid glands. 

The mode of infection is inhalation or contact through the conjunctiva. The virus infects the respiratory tract leading to replication and dissemination through the cervical lymph nodes and bloodstream. The incubation period is about 12-25 days

Mumps infection usually presents with unilateral or bilateral parotid swelling. Unilateral disease usually progresses to bilateral involvement. It is accompanied by fever, local pain and tenderness but the skin over the gland is not warm or erythematous. It is usually self-limiting and resolves within a week. However, the involvement of other organs is detrimental and leads to severe complications.

Complications of mumps infection: 

  1. Epidymo-orchitis (Option A) is characterized by swollen, intensely painful testicles. This is usually associated with fever and chills. This may lead to testicular atrophy and decreased sperm counts. 
  2. Meningoencephalitis (Option B) or meningitis can occur. This is usually aseptic and is characterized by pleocytosis on cerebrospinal fluid examination. This may lead to deafness as a complication. 
  3. Acute pancreatitis (Option C) can occur. This generally resolves with conservative treatment. 
  4. Arthritis may occur with monoarticular or polyarticular involvement. 
  5. Myocardial involvement: Transient ECG changes are seen. Rapidly progressive myocarditis can occur.

A typical case of mumps needs no laboratory confirmation, but in atypical cases and complications, diagnosis may be established by virus isolation and serological tests.

Prophylaxis of mumps is done through the administration of an effective live virus vaccine containing the Jeryl-Lynn strain of the virus. The vaccine is given as a single subcutaneous injection, alone or in combination with the measles and rubella vaccines (Measles - Mumps - Rubella vaccine: MMR vaccine)

questions.text: During community medicine postings, you are posted for the pulse polio immunization programme as an intern. You see only polio vaccine drops being administered orally to all children within the age of 0-5 years. Which of the following statements is true regarding types of vaccines against Polio?

choices.text: Salk type has the live attenuated virus
OPV can be administered in immunocompromised persons
Salk type vaccine is associated with mutations that lead to reversal of virulence
Both OPV and IPV induces humoral Ig

questions.solution:
Both OPV (Oral polio vaccine) and IPV (Inactivated polio vaccine) induce humoral IgG and IgM antibodies. OPV also induces local immunity in the lining of the intestine.

There are two types of vaccine that protect against polio: inactivated poliovirus vaccine (IPV) and oral poliovirus vaccine (OPV).

  1. OPV – Sabin:
    • OPV initially consisted of a mixture of live attenuated poliovirus strains of each of the three serotypes. OPV used in India contained, Type 1 virus 10 lakh, Type 2 virus 2 lakh and Type 3 virus 3 lakh TC ID50 per dose (0.5 ml). Trivalent vaccine has now been replaced by bivalent OPV, by removing the type 2 component from immunisation programmes (OPV switch)
    • OPV produces antibodies in the blood (humoral immunity) to all three types of poliovirus, and in the event of infection, this immunity protects the individual against polio paralysis by preventing the spread of poliovirus to the nervous system.
    • OPV strains also produce a local immune response in the lining of the intestines. The antibodies produced there inhibit the multiplication and shedding of wild (naturally occurring) virus. This is the reason why mass campaigns with OPV given simultaneously (called pulse polio immunisation) have shown to help in protecting the individual and the community, producing herd immunity.
    • A strain of poliovirus in OPV may change and revert to a form that causes paralysis, leading to vaccine derived poliomyelitis (VDPV) in humans. This may also develop the capacity for sustained circulation among the community, and is known as a circulating VDPV (cVDPV). Most of the cases of cVDPV are due to the type 2 component of OPV.
  2. IPV – Salk:
    • IPV is produced from wild-type poliovirus strains of each serotype that have been inactivated (killed) with formalin.
    • As an injectable vaccine, it can be administered alone or in combination with other vaccines (e.g., diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, hepatitis B, and Haemophilus influenza).
    • Generally three spaced doses, 4-6 weeks apart are administered to generate adequate levels of seroconversion.

Other options:

  • Salk type vaccine contains killed inactivated virus.
  • OPV is not safe in immunodeficient or immunosuppressed subjects but the IPV is harmless.
  • Salk type is the killed formalized vaccine, hence there is no risk of mutation that can lead to a reversal of virulence like in case of OPV.

questions.text: A middle-aged man from West Africa developed sudden onset of fever and chills, severe headache, cough, sore throat, muscle, and joint pain. This was followed by abdominal pain and vomiting. The electron microscopy image of the likely causative agent is given below. To which bioterrorism category does it belong?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the electron microscopy image is suggestive of Ebola virus infection. It belongs to category A bioterrorism.

Ebolaviruses are long, thread-like viruses. They belong to the genus Filovirus. Three strains of the Ebola virus have been recognized: the Zaire strain (EBO-Z) with a case fatality rate of 90 percent, the Sudan strain (EBO-S) with a case fatality rate of 50 percent, and the mild Reston strain (EBO-R).

The incubation period is 3 - 25 days. The infected people develop biphasic syndrome with a 1 to 2-day relative remission. The first phase resembles influenza, characterized by sudden onset of fever and chills, severe headaches, cough, myalgia, pharyngitis, arthralgia of the larger joints, and development of a maculopapular rash. The second phase is characterized by abdominal pain with vomiting and/or diarrhea, chest pain, cough, postural hypotension, edema, and confusion, coma, headache. Hemorrhagic manifestations such as subconjunctival injection, epistaxis, hematemesis, hematuria, and melena are typical.

It spreads from person to person through direct contact with body fluids such as blood, urine, sweat, semen, and breast milk. Viral particles can be found in semen up to 61 days after illness onset from recovered cases.

Diagnosis is made through the detection of Ebola virus antigen, RNA, or antibodies in the blood. Treatment includes supportive care with aggressive fluid and electrolyte replacement

Bioterrorism is the deliberate release of an agent by attackers that causes one or more of a variety of different diseases. Category A (High risk) pose a threat to national security and has the ability to cause social disruption. Examples include Ebola, anthrax, botulism, plague, smallpox, and tularemia.

questions.text: Working as a duty doctor in a COVID care centre, you were trained on sanitation techniques, donning, doffing of PPE and other preventive measures to reduce the incidence of disease. You were recommended to use alcohol-based hand rubs to curtail the spread of COVID-19 infection. The microbiological basis for the same would be?

choices.text: COVID-19 virus has a lipid envelope
COVID-19 virus has a glycoprotein capsid

questions.solution:
Alcohol-based hand rubs are preferred because COVID 19 virus has a lipid envelope that contributes to its susceptibility to lipid solvents. 

Coronaviruses are enveloped helically symmetrical viruses. Alcohol, especially ethanol present in the hand rubs, dissolves the lipid envelope and denatures the proteins present. This leads to membrane disruption and inhibition of the metabolism, as depicted below:

The Coronaviridiae have a single unsegmented ss (+) RNA which is, in fact, the largest genome among RNA viruses. They are about 120 - 160 nm in size and contain a helical nucleocapsid. They have club-shaped or petal-shaped projections that are widely spaced on the outer surface of the envelope, suggestive of a solar corona.

The virus has spike proteins - S1 and S2 which are responsible for the host specificity, faster spread of the disease, and make it highly susceptible to mutations. While S1 protein is involved in the attachment of the virus with the ACE-2 receptor, S2 protein is involved in virus-host cell fusion. 

The virus responsible for the pandemic that started in 2019 is named SARS-CoV-2 (severe acute respiratory syndrome- coronavirus-2) and the disease it causes has been named coronavirus disease 2019 (abbreviated COVID-19). 

SARS-CoV-2 is a member of the order Nidovirales, family Coronaviridae, subfamily Orthocoronavirinae, and is considered to be a new member of the genus Betacoronavirus.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with subcutaneous mycosis. Which of the following infections is an example of this?
questions.solution:
Sporotrichosis is an example of a subcutaneous mycosis. The other three conditions present as systemic mycosis.

Subcutaneous mycoses are usually caused by traumatic inoculation of the causative fungus in skin. Fungi causing such subcutaneous mycoses are either normally present in the soil or are pathogens of plant. These include:

  • Mycotic mycetoma
  • Chromomycosis
  • Sporotrichosis
  • Rhinosporidiosis
  • Subcutaneous phycomycosis

Sporotrichosis is caused by a dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii. It usually follows minor trauma like thorn prick in rose gardeners, forest workers, etc. and is more common in Himalayan hilly areas (Himachal Pradesh).

Nodules develop first at the site of the lesion and later undergo necrosis and ulceration. This is called cutaneous sporotrichosis. There is spread along lymphatics to lymph nodes which become enlarged, supportive, and indurated. This is called lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis which is characterised by presence of cord like, hardened lymphatics.

Diagnosis:

  • On histopathology, asteroid bodies are seen with rounded or oval, basophilic, yeast-like bodies 3-5 μmin diameter, with rays of an eosinophilic substance radiating from the yeast cell
  • Culture – Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia. S.schenckii is a dimorphic fungus occurring in the yeast phase (in tissues and in cultures) at 37°C, and in the mycelia phase (in nature and cultures) at 25°C.

Treatment:

  • Cutaneous form – Potassium iodide oral or topical
  • Lymphocutaneous form – Itraconazole
  • Disseminated infection – Amphotericin B

questions.text:
A microbiologist was studying a fungal cell wall polysaccharide called glucan, which has been used for the diagnosis of certain invasive fungal infections. Which of the following fungal infections can be detected by this assay?

1. Invasive aspergillosis
2. Invasive candidiasis
3. Invasive cryptococcosis
4. Pneumocystis jiroveci infection
questions.solution:
The given diagnostic assay is a 1, 3 beta D Glucan assay. Invasive aspergillosis, invasive candidiasis, and infection with Pneumocystis jiroveci are detected by this assay. But, invasive cryptococcosis is not detected by this assay. It is diagnosed by the detection of the cryptococcus capsular polysaccharide.

Fungi have an essential rigid cell wall that determines their shape and protects them from environmental stresses. Cell walls are made up of carbohydrate layers, glycoproteins, and lipids. It has components such as chitin, glucan, and mannans which are cross-linked to form a multilayered cell wall matrix. In addition, other polysaccharides may be unique to specific fungal species and therefore useful for identification.

1,3-β-d-glucan (BDG) is a cell wall polysaccharide composed of glucose polymers and is found in most fungi, more commonly: candida, aspergillus, and Pneumocystis jiroveci.  

However, it is not detectable in the fungi such as cryptococci, zygomycetes, and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.  

This assay is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) used to detect beta D Glucan by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes. These cells contain factors C and G which are components of the Limulus clotting cascade. Factor C initiates coagulation in the presence of bacterial liposaccharide and factor G initiates coagulation in the presence of Beta D Glucan. By eliminating factor C from the lysate, the manufacturers limit activation of the cascade to Beta D glucan alone.

Match the following parasites with their respective hosts:
1. Diphyllobothrium latum a. Sheep
2. Paragonimus westermani b. Crayfish
3. Brugia malayi c. Cyclops
4. Fasciola hepatica d. Mansonia
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is 4-a, 2-b, 1-c, 3-d.

Diphyllobothrium latum infection is acquired by eating raw or undercooked fish containing third-stage plerocercoid larva. It usually causes diphyllobothriasis (Transient abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, nausea, weakness, weight loss) and vitamin B12 deficiency by absorbing large quantities of vitamin B12 and interfering with the ileal absorption

  • Definitive hosts: Man, dog, and cat. Man is the optimal host.
  • First intermediate host: Cyclops or Diaptomus.
  • Second intermediate host: Freshwater fish (salmon, trout, etc.).

Treatment for Diphyllobothrum latum infection is Praziquantel.

The image below shows the life cycle of Diphyllobothrium latum 

 

Paragonimus westermani (lung fluke) infection is acquired by consuming freshwater crab/crayfish containing metacercariae. It causes pulmonary symptoms similar to pulmonary tuberculosis (coughing and hemoptysis).

  • Definitive host: Man, cats, tigers, leopards, foxes, dogs, pigs, beavers, and domestic animals
  • First intermediate host: Freshwater snail
  • Second intermediate host: Freshwater crab or crayfish.

The adult worms live in the respiratory tract of the definitive host in cystic spaces surrounded by a fibrous capsule formed by the host tissues. Unembryonated eggs escape into the bronchi and are coughed up and voided in sputum or swallowed and passed in feces.

Praziquantel (25 mg/ kg TDS for 1-2 days) is the drug of choice.

The given image shows the life cycle of Paragonimus westermani

 

Fasciola hepatica is a liver fluke that resides in the liver and the lumen of the biliary passages and causes fascioliasis. It mainly affects sheep and other domestic animals. Infection in sheep and man is acquired by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation.

  • Definitive host: Sheep, goat, cattle, and man.
  • Intermediate host: Snails of the genus Lymnaea and Succinea. Encystment occurs on aquatic plants, which act as second intermediate host.

Oral triclabendazole (10 mg/kg once) is the treatment of choice

Life cycle of Fasciola hepatica

 

Brugia malayi causes filariasis in man. The intermediate host of Brugia are vectors of genera Mansonia. In India, main vectors are Mansonia annulifera and M. uniformis.

Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice. It is given orally in a dose of 6 mg/ kg body weight daily for a period of 12 days.

questions.text: Which of the following stages of Entamoeba histolytica is considered as an infective form?
questions.solution:
Mature quadrinulceate cyst is considered as the infective form of Entamoeba histolytica. It is passed in feces and can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days.

The cysts are present only in the lumen of the colon and in formed feces. They initially contain a glycogen vacuole and chromatoid bodies (masses of ribonucleoprotein) with characteristic rounded ends. Nuclear division occurs within the cyst and results in a mature quadrinucleated cyst which has 4 nuclei. The chromatid bodies and glycogen vacuoles disappear.

Other options:

They include various life stages of Entamoeba histolytica

Trophozoite:

  • The trophozoite is the vegetative or growing stage of the parasite.
  • It is found only in tissues
  • The cytoplasm has two zones, a hyaline outer margin and a granular inner region that may contain red blood cells (pathognomic)
  • Pseudopodia are present which exhibit gliding motility
  • Nucleus has a central karyosome with radiating fibrils called linin network giving a cartwheel appearance.

Precystic stage:

  • This is formed when the trophozoid extrudes its food vacuoles and becomes round or oval, just before encystment.
  • It has a large glycogen vacuole and 2 chromatid bars
  • It secretes a refractile cyst wall to further become a cyst

Metacystic trophozoites:

  • This is formed after excystation of the mature cyst once it reaches the intestine. 
  • Initially, the cytoplasm gets detached from the cyst wall and there is a tear in the cyst wall, through which quadrinucleate amoeba is liberated. This stage is called the metacyst.
  • The nuclei in the metacyst immediately undergo division to form eight nuclei, which get surrounded by their own cytoplasm to become eight small amebulae or metacystic trophozoites.

The octanucleate cyst is seen in the case of Entamoeba coli, which is a non-pathogenic commensal amoeba.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with severe headache, photophobia and high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilledema and nuchal rigidity was present. Kernig's and Brudzinski signs were positive.  CSF examination shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. Causative organism is:
questions.solution:
History, physical examination, and CSF findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis. The given image shows intracellular Gram-negative diplococci i.e. Neisseria meningitidis.

The genus Neisseria consists of Gram-negative, aerobic, non-sporulating, non-motile, oxidase-positive cocci arranged typically in pairs (diplococci). It includes two pathogens: Neisseria meningitidis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The important difference is the presence of a polysaccharide capsule in N meningitidis.

The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx. From the nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteremia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection. Clinical features include fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation (nuchal rigidity, Kernig's sign, Brudzinski's signs). Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash due to petechial hemorrhages.

Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.

The selective medium used is the Modified Thayer-Martin medium (with vancomycin, colistin, and nystatin). The colonies are seen as small, translucent, convex, bluish-grey, with a smooth glistening surface and lenticular in shape on solid media.

Intravenous penicillin G is the treatment of choice. Eradicative therapy is to be given with rifampicin or ciprofloxacin to prevent the carrier state.

Chemoprophylaxis is indicated for the household and close contacts. The preferred antibiotics are rifampin, ciprofloxacin, and ceftriaxone. Monovalent, polyvalent, and conjugate vaccines are available.

Other options:

Option A: Haemophilus influenzae type B is a gram-negative bacillus with considerable polymorphism. In sputum, clusters of coccobacillary forms are seen; In CSF, long bacillary filamentous forms predominate. H. influenzae b grows on chocolate agar (which supplies necessary nutrients from lysed red blood cells) or on blood agar (appear as satellite colonies surrounding β-hemolytic colonies of S. aureus).

Option C: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram positive, capsulated, flame shaped or lanceolate shaped diplococci. In culture, the typical morphology may not be apparent and the cocci are more rounded, tending to occurjp short chain

Option D: Listeria monocytogenes is a short, non sporing, gram positive bacillus. It shows characteristic tumbling motility at 25°C, but is non motile at 37°C.

questions.text: A senior resident uses Diene’s stain to stain the micro-organisms which appear as shown below. This characteristic appearance is shown by which of the following bacteria?
questions.solution:
Diene's method of staining is used for diagnosis of mycoplasma. It is also known as Eaton agent since Eaton was the first person to isolate Mycoplasma pneumoniae. 

The colony is typically biphasic, with a fried egg appearance, consisting of a central opaque granular area of growth extending into the depth of the medium, surrounded by a flat, translucent peripheral zone. 

Mycoplasma colonies can be studies either with a hand or after staining with Diene's method. For Diene's method, a block of agar containing the colony is cut and placed on a slide. It is covered with a cover slip on which an alcoholic solution of methylene blue and azure has been dried. 

Mycoplasma are the smallest free-living microorganisms and they can be grown in a cell-free medium. They lack a cell wall and are higly pleomorphic. They occur as granules and filaments of various sizes. They were previously called pleuropneumonia-like organisms (PPLO) since they were thought to cause pleuropneumonia in many animals and humans.

The species of mycoplasma causing human infections are:

  • M.pneumoniae causing pneumonia
  • Ureaplasma urealyticum causing non-gonococcal urethritis
  • M.hominis and M.gentalium causing genital tract infections.

questions.text: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The life cycle shown in the above image is suggestive of leptospirosis. 

It is caused by contact with the urine or blood of an infected organism. It is a zoonotic disease, with rats being the most well-known reservoirs. 

Illness is classically biphasic after an incubation period of up to 1 month. The stages are: 

  • Acute leptospiremic phase- organism can be cultured from blood.
  • Resolving immune phase- organism can be cultured from urine.

The stages may not be clinically distinguishable.

Most cases are asymptomatic but a few may present with severe manifestations. Clinical features include: 

  • High-grade fever
  • Hepatic dysfunction 
  • Renal impairment
  • Hemorrhages- gastrointestinal, pulmonary (most common), petechiae and purpura

The severe form is known as Weil's disease, with a triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. 

Treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone.

questions.text: A young female patient with a recent travel history comes to the OPD with a history of prolonged abdominal pain, diarrhea, and fever gradually increasing in a step ladder pattern. On examination, faint, salmon-colored macules are seen on the trunk. A serological test is used to confirm the diagnosis. This test is an example of
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of enteric fever/ typhoid fever. Widal test is an agglutination test done in case of typhoid fever.

Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella typhi. The clinical course may vary from mild undifferentiated pyrexia to a rapidly fatal disease. Clinical manifestations include malaise, step ladder pyrexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and myalgia. Hepatosplenomegaly is a common finding on examination. Rose spots are small erythematous maculopapular lesions that are seen on the chest and abdomen that fade on pressure. They appear in the second week and are seen as shown below

Widal test:

It is a type of tube agglutination test in which, H and O agglutinins for typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli are measured in the serum sample. It is performed by mixing equal volumes (0.4 ml) of serial dilutions of the serum (from 1/10 to 1/640) with fixed volumes of H and O antigens in the Dreyer's and Felix agglutination tubes, respectively. These tubes are incubated overnight and the agglutination titres are read. H agglutination leads to the formation of cotton woolly clumps while O agglutination is seen as a disc-like pattern at the bottom of the tube.

Interpretation of Widal test: 

  • Demonstration of a rise in titre of antibodies by testing two or more serum samples is more meaningful than a single test.
  • H agglutinin titer > 1/640 and O agglutinin titer >1/320 is considered significant.

Other options

  • Option b: In tube flocculation test, serial dilutions of the toxin/ toxoid are added to tubes containing a fixed quantity of antitoxin. The amount of toxin or toxoid that flocculates optimally with one unit of the antitoxin is defined as Lf dose. Example: Kahn test for syphilis.
  • Option c: In slide flocculation test, a drop each of the antigen and antiserum are placed on the slide and mixed by shaking; appearance of floccules is taken as positive. Eg. VDRL test for syphilis
  • Option d: In Ring precipitation test, antigen solution is layered over a column of antiserum in a narrow tube. the precipitate is formed at the junction of the 2 liquids. Example: Ascoli’s thermoprecipitin test for detection of anthrax antigen.

Tube flocculation, slide flocculation and ring precipitation test are all types of precipitation tests.

questions.text: Pertussis toxin acts by which of the following mechanism?
questions.solution:
Pertussis toxin acts by ADP-Ribosylation. It is expressed on the surface of Bordatella pertussis and is secreted into the environment.

Bordatella pertussis is a gram negative capsulated coccobacilli which causes whooping cough/pertussis (pertussis meaning intense cough)

Detection of bacilli in the upper respiratory tract by microscopy or culture confirms diagnosis. Respiratory samples can be collected by per-nasal swab, post-nasal swab or using the cough plate method. 

The Bordet-Gengou medium is used to culture the bacilli which are seen as small, dome-shaped, greyish white, refractile and glistening colonies, resembling 'bisected pearls' or 'mercury drops'. Confluent growth presents an 'aluminium paint' appearance.

 

 

Bordetella pertussis produces 3 hemagglutinins:

  • Pertussis toxin (PT)
  • FHA (Filamentous hemagglutinin)
  • Lipid factor

PT plays a major role in the pathogenesis of whooping cough. It acts by promoting lymphocytosis, increasing sensitization to histamine, and enhanced insulin secretion by means of ADP ribosylation that disrupts function of signal transduction in many cell types. FHA is responsible for facilitating the adhesion of Bordetella pertussis to the respiratory epithelium. FHA and PT also promote secondary infection by coating other bacteria such as Haemophilus influenzae and Pneumococci and assisting their binding to respiratory epithelium. This phenomenon has been termed 'piracy of adhesins'

Whooping cough is treated with erythromycin or one of the newer macrolides such azithromycin.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male student presented with diarrhea and acute onset cough with thick sticky sputum. There is a history of repeated lung infections since childhood. Chest Xray shows evidence of bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis. A gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacteria  is isolated which exhibits the following color change on Mueller-Hinton agar. All of the following conditions are caused by this bacteria except?
questions.solution:
The image shows the production of blue-green-colored pyocyanin, a pigment produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa which causes lung infection in the case of cystic fibrosis patients. Glanders disease is caused by Burkholderia Mallei, not pseudomonas.

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive exocrinopathy affecting multiple epithelial tissues. The gene product responsible for CF is the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) which produces defective (CFTR) protein in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, and pancreas.  

In the lungs, abnormal CFTR leads to thick, sticky mucus with abnormal mucociliary clearance. The patient will have recurrent respiratory infections with the development of bronchiectasis. Patients with cystic fibrosis also have fat malabsorption secondary to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, hence the increased stool fat.

A complex bacterial flora that includes Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa is routinely cultured from CF sputum. Infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa is common in adults with CF and it exhibits a stereotypic mode of pathogenesis; a sentinel and early colonization event that poses risk of lifelong pulmonary infection by the same genetic strain.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacteria. Pyocyanin is a bluish-green pigment, produced only by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and not produced by any other Pseudomonas species. Pigments produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and many other species include Pyoverdin (Greenish-yellow), Pyorubin (Red), Pyomelanin (Brown). Production of a combination of pyocyanin and pyoverdin can be visualised as a blue green color on Mueller Hinton agar plate.

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

  • Opportunistic infections and hospital acquired infections
  • Shanghai fever: It manifests as severe enteric disease and sepsis with invasive disease in previously healthy infants.
  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Jacuzzi syndrome (Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis) is a common type of folliculitis, which causes inflammation of hair follicles.
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum - Hemorrhagic necrosis of skin occurs often in sepsis caused by P. aeruginosa. It usually occurs in patients who are critically ill and immunocompromised. The characteristic lesions of ecthyma gangrenosum are hemorrhagic pustules that evolve into a necrotic (black) ulcer.
  • Green-nail syndrome: It results from frequent submersion of the hands in water. Infection with Pseudomonas causes diffusion of pyocyanin into the nail bed.

Glander's disease is caused by Burkholderia mallei. It is a disease primarily of equine animals (horses and mules) but, capable of being transmitted to other animals and to human beings (among grooms and veterinarians).

Image: Ecthyma gangrenosum. Note the black central eschar surrounded by an erythematous edematous halo.

questions.text: A young man presented with a single painless ulcer on the genitalia without any lymph nodes enlargement. Microscopic examination of a smear from the lesion showed the following finding. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
The causative organism is Klebsiella granulomatis. The image shows Donovan bodies in a WBC showing closed-safety pin appearance. This finding along with the clinical presentation is suggestive of granuloma inguinale/ donovanosis.

Granuloma inguinale, or donovanosis, is a sexually transmitted chronic inflammatory disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, a minute, encapsulated, Coccobacillus.

The incubation period varies from 8-80 days, the average being 50 days.

 Four types of lesions have been described in this condition:

  • Ulcerogranulomatous - most common type with painless beefy red ulcers. They are also highly vascular and bleed on touch.
  • Hypertrophic - usually with a raised irregular edge
  • Necrotic - offensive smelling ulcer that causes tissue destruction
  • Sclerotic or cicatricial - with fibrous or scar tissue

Primary lesions can occur on genital and extragenital sites. Lesions are not usually accompanied by lymphadenopathy, but subcutaneous extension of granulo­mas may mimic enlarged lymph nodes (called pseudobuboes). 

The diagnosis is usually made by microscopic presence of Donovan bodies in Wright/Giemsa-stained impression smears. They appear as rounded coccobacilli within cystic spaces inside large mononuclear cells. They show bipolar condensation of chromatin giving a closed safety-pin appearance.

Treatment consists of prolonged antibiotic therapy, for a period of 6 weeks with oral azithromycin (1st line), or oral doxycycline (2nd line).

questions.text: A 32-year-old laborer working at a construction site presented with fever and hemoptysis. The sputum sample collected for examination showed the following. The smear will be stained by which of the following sequences?

choices.text: Methylene blue - malachite green- acetic acid-water

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of fever and hemoptysis in a labourer with the sputum smear showing acid-fast bacilli is suggestive of tuberculosis. Mycobacterium tuberculosis, detected on sputum smear, is appreciated by Ziehl-Neelsen staining, which would includes carbol fuschin - acid - alcohol - methylene blue. 

Acid-fast bacteria (like MTB) in a stained Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) smear appear bright red against a blue background. Steps involved in ZN staining are:

  • Place the sample on slide evenly spread it with rotational movement
  • Air-dry the slide and fix it by passing it over a flame
  • Apply carbol fuschin stain and heat to fix it.
  • Wash with water to remove excess stain
  • Decolourise with alcohol
  • Apply Methylene blue/Malachite green stain
  • Wash with water to remove excess stain
  • View under the microscope

Kinyoun modified the classical ZN staining such that heat fixing is not required. It is called the cold method. It involves increasing the concentration of phenol acid and the duration of staining. The slide is then washed with water and decolourized with acid alcohol. Counterstaining with Loeffler's methylene blue or malachite green is done for a minute and viewed under a microscope. Acid-fast bacteria in a stained smear appear bright red against a blue background.  

The image attached below summarizes the steps.

Option A: It depicts the order of Gram staining, which was discovered by Hans Christian Gram in 1884.

  • Primary staining with para-rosaniline dye (crystal violet, methyl violet or gentian violet).
  • Application of dilute solution of iodine.
  • Decolorisation with an organic solvent (ethanol, acetone, aniline).
  • Counterstaining with the dye of contrasting colour (carbol fuchsin, safranine, neutral red).

 Option B: It includes the steps for performing Albert's stain which is used for detected Corynebacterium diphtheriae. 

  • A heavy smear of the bacterial isolate is prepared on a glass slide and allowed to dry without fixing.
  • Albert’s stain is applied for (3-4) minutes. Then it is washed with water and Albert’s iodine is applied for one minute.
  • Wash with water and let dry with blotting paper.
  • Examine the slide under oil immersion.

Corynebacterium diphtheriae are slender bacilli with an arrangement resembling the letters V or L. They have metachromatic granules at the poles of bacilli which are also called polar bodies, volutin, or Babes-Ernst granules. Albert staining is useful in the demonstration of metachromatic granules. The presence of metachromatic granules helps to distinguish C.diphtheriae from diphtheroids which lack them. The images below show Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with breathing difficulty, poor feeding, and constipation. Upon examination, the physician notes a weak cry, paralysis, and loss of head control. A toxin screen of the stool identified the agent. The mother gives a recent history of feeding honey. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition?

choices.text: This condition is caused by an exotoxin
The toxin type G is associated with sudden death
Detection of antitoxin can aid in diagnosis
The toxin causes spastic paralysis by blocking the release of Acetylcholine

questions.solution:
The above clinical picture is suggestive of infant botulism. Statement 4 is the false statement since the toxin causes flaccid paralysis by blocking the release of acetylcholine.

Botulism is caused by Clostridium botulinum, and is of three types:

  • Foodborne botulism
  • Infant botulism
  • Wound botulism

Infant botulism (also called floppy baby syndrome): It is usually seen in infants less than 6 months; It is acquired by ingestion of foods like honey contaminated with C. botulinum spores. It gets established in the gut and produces toxin. The characteristic clinical history is paralysis, constipation, difficulty breathing, poor feeding, weak, altered cry, and loss of head control. Diagnosis is confirmed by detecting toxin or spores in the stool. Gram staining shows gram-positive, sporing bacilli. It is managed by supportive care and assisted feeding only.

Other options:

  • Clostridium botulinum produces a powerful exotoxin that is responsible for its pathogenicity.
  • The toxin type G is associated with sudden death.
  • A retrospective diagnosis can be made by detection of antitoxin in the serum but it may not be seen in all cases.

The organism shown in the image is the Nocardia asteroides. They are modified acid-fast positive and appear as branching, filamentous rods. Patients with nocardiosis usually present with symptoms mimicking tuberculosis, such as fever, cough, night sweats.  

Nocardia are gram-positive strict aerobes found particularly in the soil and are found to produce lung infections mostly in the immunocompromised.

Pleuropulmonary nocardiosis is the main presentation and usually manifests as pneumonia, lung abscess, or other lesions resembling tuberculosis. Symptoms may include fever, night sweats, weight loss, chest pain, cough with or without sputum production, and shortness of breath.

Hematogenous spread from the lung is most frequently to the brain. Other common sites include skin, kidneys, bones, muscles, and eyes, but almost any organ can be involved. Cutaneous infection may lead to local abscesses, cellulitis, lymphocutaneous lesions or actinomycotic mycetoma.
