questions.text: What is Elek’s gel precipitation test used to test?
questions.solution:
Elek's test is used to test the toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Elek's gel precipitation test is an in vitro immunoprecipitation (immunodiffusion) test used to determine whether or not a strain of Corynebacterium diphtheriae is toxigenic.  In this test, a rectangular strip of filter paper impregnated with diphtheria antitoxin is placed on the surface of a 20% normal horse serum agar. Narrow streaks of the C. diphtheriae strains are made at right angles to the filter paper strip with positive and negative controls. If the strain produces toxins, the toxin will diffuse in the agar and produce a line of precipitation (arrowhead) where it meets the antitoxin at optimum concentration. 

The test is shown in the image below.

Option A: For checking susceptibility to diphtheria, Schick test is used.

Option B: The biotype of diphtheria can be determined based on colony morphology and biochemical reactions.

Option D: The antibody titer against diphtheria can be measured by various serological methods like passive haemagglutination, latex agglutination test, toxoid enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (Toxoid-ELISA), and toxin-binding inhibition ELISA (ToBI-ELISA).

questions.text: Identify the bacteria based on the culture and microscopy findings shown below.
questions.solution:
The culture showing alpha hemolysis on blood agar, with optochin (Op) sensitivity, and microscopy showing gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci, suggests Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus).

S. pneumoniae (pneumococci) is a member of the S. mitis group. The virulence of the organism is a function of its polysaccharide capsule, which prevents or delays ingestion by phagocytes.

They are normal inhabitants of the upper respiratory tract of 5–40% of humans but can cause pneumonia, sinusitis, otitis, bronchitis, bacteremia, meningitis, and peritonitis. Clinical features of pneumococcal pneumonia include sudden onset fever, chills, sharp pleural pain, and cough with bloody/ rusty sputum.

Diagnosis is by the presence of typical gram-positive diplococci in stained sputum samples. After some time, the organisms rapidly become gram-negative and tend to lyse spontaneously. This autolysis of pneumococci is greatly enhanced by surface-active agents, such as ox bile (10%) or sodium deoxycholate (2%).

Pneumococci are alpha-hemolytic on blood agar, and this is seen as greening of agar around the colonies. It is sensitive to optochin and shows a zone of inhibition, more than 14 mm around the optochin disk. This helps to differentiate pneumococcus from Streptococcus viridans.

They show characteristic Quellung reaction. When pneumococci of a certain type are mixed with specific antipolysaccharide serum of the same type (or with polyvalent antiserum) on a microscope slide, the capsule swells markedly and is seen as a halo around the organism. A positive reaction shows clumping because of cross-linking of the antibodies and pneumococci.

questions.text:
A few cases of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection are reported in the surgical ward of your hospital. All of the following are important strategies in containing the spread of MRSA infection except:
  1. Proper hand hygiene
  2. Surveillance for nasal colonization among high-risk individuals
  3. Routine antimicrobial prophylaxis for patients hospitalized for more than 48 hours
  4. Contact isolation of MRSA - carriers or infection
  5. Aseptic management of skin lesion
questions.solution:
All of the above are important strategies in containing the spread of MRSA infection except option 3, that is, routine antimicrobial prophylaxis for patients hospitalized for more than 48 hours.

Routine antimicrobial prophylaxis is not indicated in all hospitalized patients for containing the spread of Methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. All the other measures given above are taken to control MRSA infection in a healthcare setting.

Measures to prevent and control the spread of MRSA infection include:

  1. Proper hand hygiene i.e. washing the hands before and after treating the patients is the most effective way to curb the spread of MRSA infections.
  2. Aseptic management of lesions.
  3. Active surveillance testing - screening for MRSA nasal carriers in high-risk patients such as those in ICUs in the hospital setting.
  4. Contact isolation of MRSA cases and carriers.
  5. Topical mupirocin treatment for nasal carriers (MRSA decolonization therapy).
  6. Avoiding antibiotic misuse in hospitals.
  7. Bundling - performing medical procedures in a sequence of prescribed steps - reduces the rate of nosocomial infection related to the procedure.
  8. Daily chlorhexidine gluconate (CHG) bathing in intensive care units (ICUs)
  9. Cleaning and decontamination of clinical areas.

The correct steps of hand washing are given below.

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: All of the following are type IV hypersensitivity reactions except:
questions.solution:

Type IV hypersensitivity reactions (delayed hypersensitivity reactions): These reactions are induced by sensitized T cells which on contact with the specific antigen, release cytokines that produce biological effects on leucocytes, macrophages, and tissue cells.

Other examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions include systemic lupus erythematosus, serum sickness, arthus reaction, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and type II lepra reaction.

questions.text: An immunologist has arranged a series of tubes for an experiment on precipitation reaction. The tubes contain equal amounts of antiserum, while increasing quantities of antigen are added from left to right. One of the middle tubes shows maximum precipitation. What is the phenomenon observed in the tubes to the left of the middle tube?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon observed in the tubes to the left of the middle tube is called the prozone phenomenon. Here, antibodies are in excess compared to antigens leading to weak or absent precipitation.

The lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions and agglutination reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies. Precipitation occurs when a lattice consisting of alternating antigen and antibody molecules is formed.

  • The prozone phenomenon is caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. There is weak/absent precipitation, giving a false-negative test (tubes on the left side in the question stem).
  • In the zone of equivalence, antigen and antibody are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs. Lattice formation is enhanced. (tube in the middle in question stem)
  • Post-zone phenomenon is due to the presence of excessive antigens in the test system. There is weaker/absent precipitation (tubes on the right side in the question stem).


Prozone phenomenon and post-zone phenomenon can give rise to false-negative results in precipitation reactions. This can be overcome by making serial dilutions of serum, thereby optimizing the concentrations of antigens and antibodies in the test system.

Flocculation: It is a type of precipitation reaction in which the precipitate remains suspended as flocculus, instead of sedimenting.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used to demonstrate the oxygen requirements of the bacterium?
questions.solution:
The culture method used to demonstrate the oxygen requirements of a bacterium is stab culture. It is also used for demonstrating other properties like gelatin liquefaction. 

The image below shows stab culture. It is prepared by puncturing a suitable medium with a long, straight, charged wire. The oxygen-requiring bacteria will grow on the surface, and the bacteria that do not require oxygen will grow at the bottom.

Other methods used in bacterial culture:

  • Lawn culture/carpet culture: It is used for bacteriophage typing and antibiotic sensitivity testing. It is prepared by flooding the surface of the plate with a liquid culture.
  • Streak culture: It is routinely used for the isolation of bacteria in pure culture from clinical specimens. It is prepared by picking the specimen using platinum loops or straight wires and transferring it onto a well-dried plate. The inoculum is then distributed thinly over the plate by streaking it with the loop in a series of parallel lines, in different segments of the plate.
  • Pour plate culture: It gives an estimate of viable bacterial count in a suspension. It is prepared by adding appropriate dilutions of the inoculum (of 1 ml) to the molten (40-45°C) agar, which is mixed and poured into sterile petri dishes. After incubation, colonies are seen to be distributed throughout the depth of the medium. 
  • Liquid culture: These are preferred for inocula containing antibiotics and other inhibitory substances. It is prepared by inoculating liquid cultures in tubes, bottles, or flasks by touching with a charged loop, pipettes or syringe.
